snippet: The classical pianist Evgeny Kissin made a much-anticipated performance of Samuel Barber’s Sonata, along with pieces by Beethoven and Chopin, at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.
abstract: Allan Kozinn reviews concert of classical music works by Barber, Beethoven and Chopin performed by pianist Evgeny Kissin at Carnegie Hall. Photo (M)ÿ
lead_paragraph: Evgeny Kissin has built a stellar career as an interpreter of the standard Romantic canon, with Chopin and the Russian masters at its heart, and he has become an increasingly thoughtful Brahms and Beethoven pianist as well. But he has never shown much interest in American music, so when word got out that Samuel Barber's Sonata (1949) would be the centerpiece of his programs this season, longtime followers of Mr. Kissin's work were pleasantly stunned, and eager to hear what he would make of it. A performance in Tel Aviv in December has already found its way to YouTube, and on Thursday evening Mr. Kissin brought the Barber to Carnegie Hall.

headline.main: Armed With the Classics, and Reaching for More
